topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Kevin frames AI’s rapid improvement and why builders must assume models will keep getting dramatically better. Lenny introduces Kevin’s background and what the episode will cover.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Lenny reads sponsor messages for Eppo and Persona and promotes the newsletter bundle.

topics.title: Image model launch and viral Ghibli trend
topics.summary: They discuss OpenAI’s new image model launch, why it went viral, and how internal usage signaled strong product-market fit. Kevin explains the model’s instruction-following and compositional capabilities beyond style transfer.

topics.title: Defining AI, shifting baselines, and normalization
topics.summary: Kevin and Lenny explore how breakthroughs quickly become “just algorithms,” using GPT-3 and self-driving cars as examples. They highlight how fast user expectations reset as capabilities improve.

topics.title: Kevin’s recruiting story joining OpenAI
topics.summary: Kevin recounts how a planned break turned into a fast OpenAI recruiting process, including a stressful nine-day silence after interviews. The segment emphasizes ambiguity, speed, and intensity around OpenAI’s hiring.

topics.title: What’s different at OpenAI: pace and uncertainty
topics.summary: Kevin contrasts traditional product building on stable tech stacks with AI’s rapidly shifting capabilities. He explains why “fuzzy inputs/outputs” change product design and why reliability thresholds (60% vs 95% vs 99.5%) matter.

topics.title: Evals as a core skill for AI builders
topics.summary: Kevin defines evals as tests/benchmarks for model performance and argues they’re essential for building AI products. He uses Deep Research as an example of designing evals alongside product design to guide iteration and fine-tuning.

topics.title: Startup moats: where OpenAI won’t build everything
topics.summary: Kevin explains why there will always be more opportunities outside OpenAI than inside it, emphasizing vertical-specific data and workflows. He encourages startups to build industry- and company-specific AI products on top of OpenAI’s API ecosystem.

topics.title: Shipping fast: lightweight planning and iterative deployment
topics.summary: Kevin describes how OpenAI balances directional alignment with bottoms-up execution, expecting plans to change as models improve. He outlines iterative deployment, tolerance for mistakes, and “model maximalism” (avoid over-scaffolding because models will soon improve).

topics.title: Competition and coding models (Anthropic, OpenAI, others)
topics.summary: They discuss why some competitors excel at coding and how intelligence is multidimensional across tasks. Kevin predicts rapid catch-up dynamics across labs, benefiting users, and hints OpenAI has more coming.

topics.title: Why ChatGPT won mindshare and usage
topics.summary: Kevin attributes ChatGPT’s dominance to being early and to bundling many capabilities into a single “one-stop” product. He connects this to a future of more agentic tools that accomplish real tasks for users.

topics.title: Designing AI UX: reasoning latency and chain-of-thought
topics.summary: Kevin shares a counterintuitive lesson: AI product UX can be designed by analogy to human behavior (e.g., acknowledging a question before thinking). They discuss tradeoffs in exposing chain-of-thought and how OpenAI landed on summarized reasoning updates.

topics.title: Chat as an interface: universal, flexible baseline
topics.summary: Kevin argues chat is a powerful default interface because it matches how humans communicate and scales across intelligence levels. He notes specialized UIs can be better for high-volume tasks, but chat remains the catch-all interaction layer.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Lenny interviews OneSchema’s founder about FileFeeds for CSV/SFTP integrations, reliability, and validation to prevent bad data imports.

topics.title: Research and product collaboration at OpenAI (partial)
topics.summary: Kevin explains OpenAI’s evolution from a research-first org (ChatGPT as a “research preview”) toward being both world-class research and product. He notes the company is actively improving how research and product teams work together.
